title: grammar school progress not good enough says inspector
story: After a follow-up inspection, parents received a letter this week from HM Inspector Bill Geddes, who said there would now be liaison with Argyll and Bute Council to speed up improvements and another inspection will take place within one year.But Mr Geddes admitted: ‘Many of the steps being taken to improve attainment in the school have had too little time to demonstrate their impact.’Weak performance in numeracy remains a concern, and for senior pupils,there has been no substantial improvement in attainment since the original inspection was carried out.‘The school has achieved only limited success in developing a clear sense of direction,’ the report said, noting inconsistencies in teaching, but adding: ‘Staff now have a clearer understanding of the priorities in improving young people’s learning successes and achievements.’Senior leaders should improve communication with all principal teachers as ‘parents and others involved feel that communication is not currently a strength of the school’.The report also draws attention to some expressions of ‘signicant concerns about poor behaviour in the school with no apparent formal, agreed procedure for dealing with behavioural issues’.A few parents said they are concerned about the lack of response when they contact the school with a query about their child’s wellbeing.School staff came in for some criticism: ‘Major inconsistencies remain in teachers’ practice,’ the report said, ‘young people do not consistently experience appropriate pace or challenge in their learning’.After receiving this report Argyll and Bute Council said: ‘We are committed to driving forward these improvements and delivering an education service that gives our young people the support they need to secure and sustain positive destinations and achieve success in le.‘Whilst areas for further work have been identied, it is important to recognise the positive changes that have already been put in place since the initial inspection.‘Working together, our pupils and school staff are achieving success, often award-winning.‘Campbeltown Grammar is no exception, having been recently recognised at an event in the Scottish Parliament for its good practice in Holocaust education. These are the type of achievements we want to build on.‘Figures also show that almost all school leavers in Campbeltown progress to positive destinations upon leaving school.#This reiterates the message that Campbeltown Grammar has young people to be proud of and we will continue to make any improvements required to support them in developing their aspirations and achieving their ambitions.’

title: scotland should be reaping the wind jobs
story: Pat Rafferty and Gary Smith, the Scottish secretaries of Unite and GMB, gave a joint statement after a summit in Edinburgh last week to discuss the  closure of CS Wind in Campbeltown and the ongoing lack of work linked to the massive investments in wind farm and other renewable technology coming into the country.Following the event, the Scottish Government announced that Scottish companies will benefit from new steps to increase the number of offshore wind contracts staying in Scotland.Developers will have to agree on supply-chain commitments when applying for offshore wind leases, under an agreement between the Scottish Government and Crown Estate Scotland.Representatives from the UK Government, trades unions, and industry attended the Scottish Offshore Wind Sector Summit in Edinburgh to discuss solutions to the issues facing the offshore wind supply chain.Mr Rafferty and Mr Smith said in the statement: ‘We welcome these long overdue measures announced today by the Scottish Government in taking a harder line with the industry – but this must be the start of change and not the end.‘The truth is it’s been a decade of failure for job creation in Scotland’s offshore wind sector.‘In  employment in Scotland’s offshore wind sector was forecast to be , direct jobs and , indirect jobs by .‘We are nowhere near that and in the last few months redundancy notices have been handed out at supply chain firms like BiFab and CS Wind.‘In the same period, industry majors like SSE have been subsidised to the tune of billions of pounds of public money through the UK Government’s Contracts for Dferencescheme, with no link at all to domestic job creation commitments.‘It’s a scandalous story of missed opportunities and ultimately one of industrial and political failure.‘Without a detailed industrial plan involving the industry and a substantial programme of investment for our supply chain, our green jobs revolution will continue to be delivered in Spain, Saudi Arabia, UAE, Indonesia and China – anywhere but Scotland.’Speaking after the meeting, Derek Mackay MSP, Economy Secretary, admitted: ‘Scotland is the ideal location for offshore wind, but recent projects have not delivered the signicant economic opportunities we want to see for Scottish businesses.‘The Scottish Government has been calling for the offshore sector to do more by awarding contracts to our indigenous supply chain, but recent disappointments suggest that more has to be done.’He pledged: ‘I will use every lever at our disposal to ensure that our renewables supply chain benefits from the expansion of offshore wind in our waters, leading to the creation and retention of Scottish jobs.‘The measures agreed with Crown Estate Scotland will help to release more of those economic benefits for the Scottish economy and ensure that the Scottish-based supply chain is considered when tendering for work or making long-term conditions.’The minister was joined by Colin Palmer, director of marine for Crown Estate Scotland who added: ‘Scotland has unique potential when it comes to offshore wind and we’re committed to doing all we can to unlock that opportunity. ScotWind Leasing will present Scotland as an attractive destination for the signicant investment needed to deliver the scale of offshore wind projects we want to see.’Employment was on the agenda at Campbeltown Community Council’s meeting last week.Chairman Alan Baker said: ‘We discussed the unemployment in the area due to ious redundancies that were issued, namely at Campbeltown Creamery and CS Wind.‘It was felt that after the initial meeting at the MACC premises that nothing further has been forthcoming.‘There is also to be a meeting in March with Fergus Ewing MSP to discuss further action.’The Courier asked both Mr Ewing’s office and the press office at the Scottish Government but no one could confirm the meeting was taking place, or when, by the time we went to press.

title: valuable support offered to argyll businesses
story: As Scotland#s national business advice service, Business Gateway helps thousands of customers to meet their business goals every year. title: well-known-preston-lodge-school-nurse-viv-retires
story: Viv Donaldson, of Prestonpans, started off at PL in the school canteen and moved to the role of pupil auxiliary school nurse after eight years.She came to the school in her thirties when her own children were attending PL and is now leaving to help care for her three grandchildren, having celebrated her th, th and th birthdays at Preston Lodge.She ended her  years at the school on the last day of term before Christmas.During her time at the school, Viv went on multiple school trips to the Netherlands, where she went on her first ever rollercoaster she took part in school performances, attended staff weekends away, and helped fundraise as a member of the schoolrsquos fundraising group the Persian Ladies, who have raised thousands of pounds for charity.In , the school united to raise money in honour of Viv during her battle with lung cancer.Vivrsquos Walk of Positivity was held in aid of FACEand Ward : Chemotherapy Outpatients Fund, at the Western General Hospital.The Walk of Positivity continues to take place annually.Viv told the Courier: ldquoPL has been like a second home to me. My own daughters attended PL too and did very well in their education.ldquoThe school has always had the community at the centre of all they do. I feel so privileged to have worked in this incredible establishment.ldquoI have so many fond memories: there are things that pupils have said to me over the years I wonrsquot forget and we have had some funny incidents, like the time I accidentally jabbed myself with an Epipen.ldquoWe went on trips to Holland a couple of times and that is where I went on my first ever rollercoaster ndash and we wrote about it in the school blog.ldquoMy kids replied saying that they didnrsquot believe I went on. Before, I used to just stand and hold the coats.ldquoItrsquos not been a job as such. Itrsquos been a privilege to have the children allow me to give them my time and care.Headteacher Gavin Clark said: ldquoIt is very hard to capture adequately in words what Viv Donaldson means to Preston Lodge High School, or what Preston Lodge High School means to Viv.ldquoVivrsquos commitment to this school and its community has been incredible, and it is strange imagining the school without her around.ldquoHer can-do attitude, positivity and wicked sense of humour have lightened up many days, and [in her last week] Viv was overwhelmed with gts and kindness from across the school.ldquoHer next chapter in le sees her stepping up her role as a much-loved grandmother, but we know that Viv will always be connected to Preston Lodge and will never be a stranger.ldquoGood luck Viv and many, many thanks for everything that you have done for this school over many years of much appreciated service. We will all miss you!

title: josh-taylor-reveals-opponent-first-defence-world-titles
story: The Prestonpans super lightweight champion ndash who added the WBA belt to his IBF title by beating highly rated American Regis Prograis on points in the final of the World Boxing Super Series in London last October ndash will have to fulfil his mandatory obligation against -year-old Khongsong before turning his attention to locking horns with WBC and WBO belt holder Jose Ramirez in a unication bout.Like Taylor, Khongsong, who is the IBFs mandatory challenger, has won all of his  bouts, but the Thai boxer has only fought once outside of his home country.Taylor is dreaming of getting his hands on all four belts in the lbs ision but will also have to wait for the outcome of Ramirezrsquos defence against Ukrainian Viktor Postol on February .Postol and Taylor have already squared off, having fought each other in the summer of .The fight, which took place at the SSE Hydro in Glasgow, saw Taylor emerge with a unanimous points decision over Postol, who previously held the WBC title.Taylor said: ldquoRamirez has the mandatory against Postol in February and I have to do it with my IBF belt with this guy from Thailand.ldquoI need to get that out of the way and he needs to get Postol out of the way.ldquoEvenPostol comes through that hersquoll be the guy I want because hersquoll have the two belts.Taylor, who split with Barry McGuigans Cyclone Promotions last week after signing with American promoters Top Rank, is hoping to be on home soil against Khongsong but concedes he will likely have to travel across the Atlantic for a potential bout with American Ramirez.Speaking to IFLTV, he added: ldquoIrsquom hoping Irsquoll have a defence in Scotland before then going Stateside to chase the Ramirez fight.ldquoI canrsquot see Ramirez coming over here, Irsquod push for it but I have to go to America.ldquoIrsquoll go there and see my name up in bright lights."The future is bright and I canrsquot wait to get going.ldquoThat fight has to happen at some point this year, thats my goal and focus, becoming undisputed king and be the first [Scottish] man to do it since Ken Buchanan.

title: long-serving-dunbar-grammar-school-dinner-lady-retires-31-years
story: Sheila Martin, , was born and brought up in Galashiels, moving to Dunbar when she married husband Derek nearly  years ago.Derek, who used to work at Dunbar cement works, sadly passed away from cancer five years ago.The pair had two children: Kevin, , a labourer at a local farm, and Joanne, .Before Dunbar Grammar, Sheila worked nightsht at Torness Power Station.A former colleague provided relief at the school when staff were off sick.Sheila covered for her one day and, after her third time providing relief, stayed at the school ever since.Working at the school for  years, Sheila has witnessed a lot of changes over the years.She said: ldquoThe job has changed quite a bit over the years ndash this place is a lot busier than it used to be.ldquoIt is a lot harder and you donrsquot always have the right amount of staff, someone is always off sick.ldquoThat just puts pressure on and you get a bit grumpy some days when yoursquore short staffed. It can be quite crazy some days, especially when you have a delivery coming in.She added: ldquoWhen I first came, the pupils had their dinner ndash a standard meat and two veg, and a pudding ndash that was it and we used to transport meals out to places like West Barns and Innerwick schools and also used to do meals on wheels in here.ldquoThere was a milk bar and we had to wash the dishes by hand.ldquoThey are going back to main meals now but there is a lot of fast food kids can have too.ldquoWhen I first started, all of the food, including meat and veg, was prepared fresh unlike now, where it is mostly frozen.Her colleague Lorraine Batchelor added: ldquoThe kitchen used to be a lot bigger than it is now it was also all wooden apart from the marble slab for their pastries.ldquoPeople donrsquot realise how much work is involved in being a dinner lady ndash they think itrsquos as simple as coming in and preparing food but therersquos more to it than that.Sheila has plenty of stories from her long career, with many laughs shared between her and her colleagues.Lorraine said: ldquoWersquove had heartache, wersquove had laughs, wersquove had everything as a team.The ladies recalled that during the schoolrsquos refurbishment, one colleague went to take a cover off an electric fly trap and ended up with a face covered in dust.Lorraine added: ldquoWe laughed forever ndash all you could see were her eyes!Another tale involved trying to catch a mouse which Lorraine ended up standing on.Other standout moments included end-of-term parties and the many silly moments and jokes shared with her colleagues.When asked about the pupils, Sheila said: ldquoThey are a good bunch of kids ndash Lorraine and I have quite a good rapport with them.ldquoYou meet them outside in the street when shopping and they stop and say hello. Some kids Irsquove served have went on to have their own kids and I have served them too.ldquoSome students were upset to hear I was leaving ndash you get to know them and what they like. I canrsquot say anything bad about the kids at all.There are a lot of things Sheila ndash who finished at the school at the Christmas holidays ndash is going to miss, including laughs with her colleagues and interaction with the pupils.Claire Slowther, headteacher at Dunbar Grammar School, said: ldquoItrsquos a huge thing to have worked somewhere for so long.ldquoShersquos lovely and so caring with the kids, certainly all the staff in our bistro are, they never see our kids go hungry and always look after the youngsters.ldquoSheila is very much a core member of the team having been here for so long but itrsquos going to be an odd sensation not having her.ldquoWersquore very much going to miss her, shersquos fantastic and such a figure, shersquos just so synonymous and a matriarch of the bistro and the school catering.Lorraine added that although her and the rest of the bistro staff were going to miss Sheila,the canteen ever needed an extra pair of hands, Sheila would be the first person they called.

title: demand-parcels-east-lothian-foodbank-reached-record-high-ahead-christmas
story: East Lothian Foodbank revealed the startling figures last week, with more than  parcels delivered in the run-up to Christmas.The foodbank, based in Tranent, also told the Courier that its annual Jingle Bags appeal resulted in more than  Jingle Bags, containing traditional Christmas fare such as mince pies, Christmas crackers and tinned turkey, being distributed to families in need.Peter Dicker, manager of the foodbank, which provides a minimum of three daysrsquo emergency food to people in crisis, thanked volunteers for their efforts at the charity and those who made donations.He said: ldquoOnce again it was a challenging month at the foodbank and I have to again thank all our volunteers for the outstanding effort they have put in this year.ldquoSome folk came in every day, many came in multiple times and we are so grateful for your help.ldquoWe were also humbled by the generosity of the East Lothian community as they responded to our Christmas appeal.ldquoWe need to analyse why this year was so busy ndash therersquos no doubt that many families are finding it harder to make ends meet with all the pressures of Christmas and, because we close over the holiday, many referral agents want to help their clients in the run-up to Christmas.Demand for food parcels has almost doubled in the last five years, with staff under intense pressure.Now, supermarket giants Asda have teamed up with The Trussell Trust and food waste charity Fareshare to launch a pound million fund to support foodbanks across the country.East Lothian Foodbank has received pound, from the fund, with the money to be spent over the next three years on staffing.Candace Higgins, who works at the Bridges Project in Musselburgh, will take on the role of foodbank director.She said: ldquoIrsquom really looking forward to supporting staff and volunteers, ensuring we deliver a gold standard emergency food service.ldquoItrsquos also vital that, as a team, we take a strategic approach to the future, developing lsquomore than foodrsquo projects which aim to actually reduce the need for food parcels in the long-term.ldquoAs always with a small charity, funding will be a key challenge, but itrsquos great that the foodbank enjoys such support with local people in East Lothian.The charity hosts its annual general meeting on January  in St Martinrsquos Church Hall, on Tranentrsquos High Street, at .pm.

title: aldi-close-existing-store-haddington-move-gateside
story: Aldi has been based on the townrsquos Whittingehame Drive for  years but staff are to move to the planned Gateside Retail Park, on the townrsquos western edge.The new store, which will be  per cent larger than the existing shop, is part of the retail park planned for Haddington, which will also feature The Food Warehouse ndash which is part of the Iceland brand ndash in one of the five units.Home Bargains and Costa are also thought to be keen to move to the site, where work has yet to start on the development.Jan Wilson, chairwoman of Haddingtonrsquos community council, was disappointed by the closure of the town centre Aldi but not surprised.She said: ldquoI thought that they would not run two stores.ldquoI just feel it is a shame for the Nungate side of the town because a lot of the people could be elderly.ldquoThey might not have a car and I just feel it is a shame for them when they had it on their doorstep.ldquoI donrsquot know what will happen to the shop when they give it up ndash whether they will sell it or not, I donrsquot know.The retail park, which will include three major retail stores, two restaurants ndash including one with a drive-thru ndash and about  parking spaces, was approved last month.It forms part of a sizeable transformation to the western entrance to the town, with hundreds of new houses being built either side of the B.A Starbucks drive-thru, to the east of the retail park, was also approved in recent months, while a petrol station and shop, to the west of the retail park, has also been given the green light.Ward councillor Craig Hoy said: ldquoAldi was a key local leline for many Nungate residents and older people living nearby.ldquoI hope that what comes next continues to serve local needs and does not further challenge High Street retailers.ldquoHaddington is changing fast and it is vital we donrsquot lose the facilities in our town centre that make it distinctive and attract to people living throughout East Lothian.ldquoWith the Gateside development having been given the green light, I will redouble my efforts to ensure I do all I can to stand up for High Street.And he added: ldquoItrsquos vital that those who live here, and those who move here, continue to have access to a sustainable town centre which offers a choice of independent, high-quality retailers. Thatrsquos what I love about our town centre and I will fight hard to preserve it.Currently, the Haddington store employs  members of staff, with that number expected to increase slightly in the new store.Aldi announced at the beginning of the year that it planned to open six new stores across Scotland during  ndashincluding at Haddington.It is also building a pound million storage and chill facility in West Lothian to service its outlets.Nationwide, that will see  new jobs created, although the number of new jobs in Haddington is expected to be minimal, with existing staff moving from Whittingehame Drive.Aldi confirmed to the Courier that it owned the Whittingehame Drive site and that ldquoa purchaser has been identied for it.ldquoHowever, any intended [future] use [of the existing store site] is unknown to Aldi, said a spokesperson.Richard Holloway, Aldirsquos regional managing director for Scotland, said: ldquoThis is an exciting time for Aldi as we plan for the next  years.ldquoOur new state-of-the-art storage and chill facility will be fully operational by the end of April, which will aid our expansion across Scotland while allowing us to increase the range of Scottish products available on our shelves.

title: tims-tales-visiting-nanas-seat
story: JESSICA was struggling. Christmas time had been dficult because it was the first Christmas without her granny, who had died earlier in the year. But now she was back at school and into the routine with her friends.Her parents had hoped this would help, but her sense of loss was still overwhelming for her. Perhaps at her age she didnrsquot understand exactly what was going on inside, but all she knew was that her granny shersquod loved was gone and she missed her.Then one evening during a bedtime story, Jessica started to cry and told her dad that her granny was melting like a snowman. At first he wasnrsquot sure what she meant, but then he understood.Jessicarsquos memory of her granny was fading. This was a second loss for her. The first loss was of her grannyrsquos physical presence, her actual hugs, her voice and care and love, even the smell of her perfume. Now Jessica was losing her memory of all this and she knew it. So she felt that something inside her was melting too, something that had been so much of her was vanishing.And this made Jessica fear that others in her le could disappear and then melt away as well, even her dad or mum. It was a terrying thought and it made her not just sad but scared and insecure inside.Her dad tried to reassure her that he or her mum werenrsquot going to die, but despite being only six years old, Jessica now knew that such promises couldnrsquot be kept forever.ldquoNana didnrsquot want to die either, but she did. And now shersquos melting.The next day at school was another dficult one for Jessica, and home time often didnrsquot make it better because in the past it had usually been her granny whorsquod picked her up.Her dad was waiting for her.ldquoWe are not going straight home today, he told her.ldquoWhere are we going ldquoTo Nanarsquos seat.A cloud suddenly came over Jessica. She didnrsquot say anything and just looked at the ground. This was a seat that overlooked the sea, where her gran had often taken her. They would sit together and look out to the Firth, spotting boats and looking for whales, while eating sweeties.Her dad had realised that Jessica hadnrsquot been there since the death of her grandmother.ldquoOnlyyou want to, he said.Jessica was silent and looked at the ground. Inside, her emotions were spinning. Then she looked up.ldquoI donrsquot want to, it will just make me sad, she said to her dad. So they didnrsquot go.But later that day, Jessica began to talk about Nanarsquos seat. ldquoShe always gave me sweeties and wersquod look for whales and pirates. She told me a story about how a pirate once landed here at Prestonpans, but he didnrsquot leave treasure, he just built the town.ldquoGreat story, said her dad.The next day, Jessica agreed to go to her nanarsquos seat. When they arrived, she hesitated to sit and had a wave of emotion.ldquoI miss Nana, she saidldquoSo do I. Shall we sit on her seat and miss her together.ldquoBut we have to eat sweeties.ldquoJust so happens Irsquove got some in my pocket, said the dad with a smile. His daughter smiled back and sat on the seat. Her dad joined her.ldquoNo, dad, that was Nanarsquos place, you sit this side instead.And so they sat, missing Nana together, being sad together, but also remembering her together.ldquoCan you tell me the story about the pirate  asked the dad.ldquoDonrsquot want to.ldquoOK, maybe next time.The next day, they ed to Nanarsquos seat. This time, Jessica told a bit of the pirate story. The dad remembered it from his childhood and realised that his own grief in losing his mother had closed him down to talking about her. It had felt too painful.He began to sit on lsquoNanarsquos seatrsquo by himself when Jessica was at school, even though he had never done it with his mother when she was alive he had always been lsquotoo busy to watch the sea with her. But his daughterrsquos anecdotes and stories about the seat made it feel like a place of remembrance for him too.The power of stories, to rekindle memory and ease the sense of loss, became very real for both Jessica and her dad. At home, they made a special box with drawings and photos of memories, and things that reminded Jessica of her gran. Theyrsquod take them out and tell stories and share memories. Her dad even began to tell funny stories about his mum from when before Jessica was born, when he was a boy.lsquoNanarsquos boxrsquo was put in a safe place, but where Jessica could take itshe wanted to. As time passed, she opened it less, but it was always in her room. Sometimes she would put things in it, such as shells from the beach, because her granny had loved beautul shells.The loss of a loved one can never be completely moved on from, so there were always going to be times of sadness. But the seat, the box and most of all the stories, stopped Jessicarsquos nana from melting.

title: giant-walking-barge-appears-off-county-coast-thorntonloch
story: Wavewalker  ndash which boasts a  metre by  metre deck area and  metre-long legs ndash is able to move across the seabed without having to be pulled or lted.One of only a few walking jack-up barges in the world, it is being used to carry out geotechnical surveys off Thorntonloch Beach, south-east of Dunbar, as part of the pound billion Neart Na GaoitheOffshore Wind Farm project.The EDF Renewablesrsquo wind farmrsquos  turbines will be erected in the outer Firth of Forth, km north of Torness. Works starts in June and should be completed in .NnGrsquos onshore grid connection is at Crystal Rig wind farm in the Lammermuir Hills, with a new substation to be built near Innerwick. The marine cables linking the wind farm to the National Grid will come ashore at Thorntonloch.Wavewalker , which has two built-in cranes, is drilling boreholes close to the shore at Thorntonloch and at its intertidal area, including the beach, in preparation for the export cables being laid.NnG, which will be much closer to the Fe coastthen East Lothianrsquos, has a capacity of about  megawatts of low-carbon energy and will offset more than , tonnes of Co emissions each year.Matthias Haag, NnG project director, said: ldquoItrsquos a really exciting time for NnG and having the WaveWalker  at Thorntonloch Beach carrying out this geotechnical survey is clear evidence of the project now entering the construction phase.ldquoThis survey will provide us with important information on the ground conditions that we need before laying the export cables that will link NnG to the National Grid via a new substation which will be built near Innerwick onshore.The WaveWalker  is specically designed to offer a safe and secure solution for marine operations in areas typically affected by weather and tides, and on beaches.Since its launch in , it has carried out a iety of operations for marine projects across the globe, including geotechnical site investigations for offshore wind farms, offshore cable installation, offshore windfarm operations and maintenance, drilling and blasting, and other underwater work.To ensure public safety during these surveys, access to Thorntonloch Beach is restricted and the public should remain at least  metres from the WaveWalker.Safety vehicles will patrol the beach  hours a day during the survey period and will be able to escort anyone wishing to cross the beach.

story: Tranentrsquos Church Street will be closed between High Street and the junction with Sandersonrsquos Wynd for six weeks from next Monday .The closure is to allow a pound, upgrade of the gas network in the area.A leaflet produced by SGN, which is behind the works, states: ldquoFor the duration of the six-week project, Church Street will be closed between its junctions with Sandersonrsquos Wynd and High Street.ldquoThere will also be no access to Church Street from Sandersonrsquos Wynd or Winton Place.ldquoFor the first two to three weeks of our work, wersquoll also have three-way temporary traffic lights in place at the junction with Bridge Street, High Street and Winton Place.ldquoWe will be manually controlling the lights at peak time to ease traffic congestion.ldquoParking suspensions in surrounding streets will be in place on Bridge Street, Church Street, Winton Place and High Street.Councillor Colin McGinn, who represents the town on East Lothian Council, said that the roadworks would cause ldquoupheaval but the gas works were necessary.He told the Courier: ldquoI think it is going to cause disruption.ldquoIt is one of those bits of work that, no matter when you do it, it is going to cause an inconvenience.Mr McGinn was also keen for the local authority to keep an eye on the works, particularly amid fears that surrounding streets, such as Coal Neuk, could be used as a rat run.Temporary Traffic Regulation Ordersare being drawn up by East Lothian Council, with temporary changes made to Winton Place to allow access to the George Johnstone Centre.Access to Sandersonrsquos Wynd will be available from Tranent Mains Road and Coalgate Road.Any queries, contact SGN on   .

title: east-links-family-park-founder-looking-take-gorgie-city-farm
story: The Edinburgh tourist attraction closed its doors last year due to financial dficulties.However, Grant Bell is keen to head up a community interest company which would see the farm opened up once again.He said: ldquoGorgie City Farm was one of the parks back in the day before East Links was created that I visited.ldquoI used photographs from Gorgie City Farm and Heads of Ayr [Farm Park] when I went to the planners with the kind of thing East Links could be.ldquoWe have a long history and traded animals for years back and forwards.Mr Bell, who opened East Links Family Park, near West Barns, in , was determined not to see the city farm remain closed.Instead, he wants it ed to its former glory, with few changes planned, other than providing somewhere with ldquoa decent cup of coffee for the facility.A statement on the tourist attractionrsquos website reads: ldquoUnfortunately, Gorgie City Farm is now closed.ldquoAfter exploring all our options, it is with huge regret that the farm has been unable to find a route to a sustainable future.ldquoWe are very grateful to all staff, volunteers, customers and donors who have supported us over the last  years.Mr Bell was aiming to make Gorgie City Farm ldquosustainable.He said: ldquoI want to keep it exactly the same ndash just farm animals and education about food and farming.ldquoI just want to get it back open and hopefully the people of Edinburgh will appreciate it.Mr Bell is one of two interested parties still in the running to potentially take over the farm.Joining him in expressing an interest is mental health charity Love Learning.Liquidator Shona Campbell, of MHA Henderson Loggie, said a decision would be made by the end of the month. A spokeswoman said: ldquoThe bidders are mental health charity Love Learning and Mr Grant Bell, owner of East Links Family Park.ldquoA consortium involving the homeless charity Cyrenians, which had previously expressed an interest, has pulled out of the process.ldquoMHA Henderson Loggie will now assess the bids before making recommendations to site landlord City of Edinburgh Council.ldquoA decision on the future of the site will be announced before the end of January.East Links Family Park, which celebrated its one millionth visitor five years ago, has a number of attractions including a soft play barn, go karts and crazy golf, as well as a wide range of both indoor and outdoor animals.Mr Bell added: ldquoI have a particular set of skills.ldquoI am a chap that comes from a farming background.ldquoI have always been interested in food and farming in the countryside and happy for visitors to come and see the farm and enjoy it.

title: north-berwick-high-school-pupils-interviewed-newsround
story: Murron Sinclair, Martha Blacklock, Charlie Bowdler, Evie Drysdale, Rab Ellis and Fergus Kinnaird, all  years old, were chosen by their teachers to take part.The aim of the interview, which took place last Thursday, was to ask the S pupils their thoughts on Scotland and a potential second independence referendum.However, a story that broke that morning about the Scottish Football Association banning children under  from heading a ball in training sessions meant the pupils were asked an additional question and appeared on the show in two separate bulletins.The Newsround team decided toto the town having visited North Berwick before when working on a plastic pollution story and have also previously visited Law Primary School.The team were speaking to three other schools during their trip to Scotland and wanted to make sure they got opinions from a iety of backgrounds and areas.In preparation for the big day, the pupils met with Georgina Brownlee, principal teacher of the schoolrsquos humanities department, two days before to find out what was going to happen and rehearse some answers.Before filming began, all of the children were nervous and scared in case they made any mistakes.Martha said: ldquoI was thinking I didnrsquot want to say the wrong thing or mess up what I was going to say.ldquoI know they can cut it but you still get a bit nervous but yoursquore also excited as yoursquore going on TV.Evie agreed and added: ldquoI didnrsquot want to sound like I didnrsquot know what I was doing.Murron said: ldquoThe thing I was most nervous about was looking straight down into a camera.Charlie added: ldquoI felt more excited than nervous. I felt relief that [the other pupils] were doing it as well becauseit was just me Irsquod feel really scared.Fergus had butterflies in his stomach and thought that being the last one to speak made them worse!The pupils were split into three pairs and asked five questions each.The first asked what they loved about Scotland, with the countryrsquos rich history, great inventors and gorgeous countryside mentioned.The pupils were then askedthey thought Scotland should be able to make its own decisions, what they thought the benefits of staying and leaving the UK were, should Scotland take back control of its own priorities and their thoughts on Boris Johnson not allowing another independence referendum.A wide range of answers were given to all of the questions, ranging from ldquoitrsquos our country and our future, we should get a say in what happens and ldquoScottish people have the right to vote as Scotland gets overpowered by England to ldquoour future could be very uncertain.Filming finished earlier than anticipated, with everyone notably a lot more relaxed afterwards.Murron and Evie were both excited to see themselves on national TV, with Murron adding: ldquoIrsquom also nervous because I donrsquot want people to come at me for my own opinion ndash I donrsquot want people to say I was wrong.Martha said: ldquoI feel quite proud that Irsquove done something like this because Irsquove never been on TV before. Irsquom almost kind of relieved that itrsquos done but also very happy with what wersquove done.The boys were equally as relieved and happy with their work, saying it was a great experience.However, the occasion was dferent than they thought it would be.The boys thought they would be greeted by five reporters, three cameras and a green screen, but only having two people, a reporter and cameraman, was a lot less daunting.All of the pupils said their parents were very excited to see them on TV and that their experience had inspired them to consider a possible career in the industry.Mrs Brownlee was very proud of the pupils and the answers they produced.She added: ldquoIt was a great opportunity and a great chance to have the kidsrsquo voices heard. The Newsround team really made them feel at ease.ldquoI quite like watching how they do it all, itrsquos really interesting.The football segment was aired last Friday and can be viewed at bbc newsround The independence piece will air next Thursdayon the .am, .am and pm bulletins.Newsround is shown on the CBBC channel and is a news show aimed at children between the ages of six and .

title: foundations-place-long-awaited-port-seton-sports-hall
story: Work on the pound million extension started last October and is due to be completed by July.The erection of the steel frame means residents can see how big the new sports hall will be.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, cabinet member for community wellbeing, said: ldquoPort Seton Centre is a much-used and valued facility in the heart of this community and there has been a long-held desire to expand its footprint to increase leisure access.ldquoOur investment will support existing services and also allow new activities to be developed.ldquoIrsquom pleased to see the progress that has been made so far and look forward to watching it continue to take shape.Marlene Love from the Port Seton Community Centre management committee said: ldquoIrsquom absolutely delighted to finally see the extension happening.ldquoItrsquos been needed for so long and itrsquos been a lot of work to make it happen.ldquo Irsquom so pleased to see it coming to fruition.Following feedback from the local community, East Lothian Council commissioned a sports hall feasibility study, which identied that the sports and leisure facilities at the existing centre were not good enough.

title: ham-sandwiches-schools-binned-date-mix-up
story: Parents were sent a message last Friday from East Lothian Council alerting them to the problem.The ham in the sandwiches was labelled with the wrong expiry date and pupils were asked to throw them away as a precaution.The schools affected were East Linton Primary, Gullane Primary, Knox Academy in Haddington, Law Primary in North Berwick, Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary in Musselburgh, Sandersonrsquos Wynd Primary in Tranent and Preston Lodge High School in Prestonpans.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoOur supplier made us aware last Friday of a product recall for roast ham, which had been provided to us for inclusion in that dayrsquos packed lunches.ldquoThe supplier informed us that an incorrect use by date had been labelled on some of the products.ldquoAs a matter of priority, we used our schools text alert system to advise parents that the ham sandwiches provided should be disposed of not consumed.ldquoSafety is paramount and we have a duty of care to all our children and young people.ldquoAs a matter of priority, our facilities management team, in consultation with environmental health, have been working with the supplier to understand the issue.ldquoWhile we believe that the incorrectly labelled ham had been dispatched to a minority of our schools, it was felt appropriate to send advice to parents at all schools as a precaution."We apologise for the inconvenience caused and can assure parents that we will continue to work with the supplier to ensure any lessons are learned for the future.

title: work-starting-ahead-railway-station-returning-east-linton
story: Campaigners have been calling for a station toto the village, on the East Coast Main Line, for more than  years.Currently, it is planned that the station will be open before , with campaigners calling for it to be in place as soon as possible.Now, a letter has been sent out to village residents highlighting upcoming work in the area.The letter reads: ldquoWe will shortly begin survey work and site investigation activity on railway land in your neighbourhood.ldquoThis work is required to help the design of a new station at East Linton.ldquoOur work will involve detailed survey activities, which may require us to cut back some vegetation.ldquoOur site investigation work also requires us to use drilling equipment to check ground conditions in proposed development sites.ldquoWhere possible, the work will be carried out during the day.ldquoHowever, some of our investigations need to be undertaken on the railway embankment or directly underneath the tracks.ldquoIn order to access these locations, we will need to carry out the work at night while trains are not operating.ldquoDuring this period of work, we will have a small compound located on site to provide facilities for our staff.ldquoThe compound will be set up from Saturday February  until our work is complete and will be located adjacent to the railway, with access taken through Orchardfield Estate, East Linton.The works come at the same time as East Lothian MSP, Iain Gray, has cautiously welcomed a response from Scotlandrsquos transport secretary on the progress of the station.Michael Mathesonrsquos response to written parliamentary questions from Mr Gray, which he submitted in light of the decision to end the Abellio ScotRail contract three years early, indicated that Network Rail are progressing with the station designs with the intention of submitting a planning application later this year.Alongside the work required for completing the station, the cabinet secretary also highlighted that an industry working group is developing plans for the December  East Coast Main Line timetable, including services for East Linton.Mr Gray was pleased progress was being made but vowed to keep the pressure on to ensure there were no delays.He said: ldquoFollowing the governmentrsquos decision to cut short Abelliorsquos ScotRail franchise, I asked parliamentary questions about progress on delivering East Lintonrsquos new rail station in order to ensure the franchise decision will not affect the project.ldquoThankfully, while the replies from Mr Matheson have not provided an exact date for the completion of the project, they have offered some reassurance that the project is progressing and the new station should be delivered by  at the latest.ldquoThat is good news for people in East Linton who have been waiting such a long time for this important new infrastructure.ldquoHowever, while the progress is welcome, there is still a signicant way to go to before it is finalised and benefitting the local community.ldquoGiven all the delays we have endured, Irsquom fully committed to maintaining the pressure on Ministers to ensure the station is delivered.East Linton previously had a railway station, which closed in .It is expected the new station will be created to the west of the previous version.

title: woman-took-valium-drove-mcdonalds
story: Ellie Watson arrived at the takeaway drive-thru at Fort Kinnaird behind the wheel of a vehicle and attempted to order food for her and her partner, who was sitting beside her.But staff soon believed the woman was under the influence of alcohol or drugs and called in the police after serving her.Officers arrived at the premises at about .am on July  last year, where they spotted Watsonrsquos vehicle in the car park.And when they spoke to the -year-old, the constables noted the woman was ldquolethargic and slurring her words and took her into custody.Watson gave a breath test soon after and also had to give a blood sample a few hours later after she had been taken to St Leonardrsquos Police Station, Edinburgh.Police officers then discovered Watson, of Delta Drive, had only a provisional driving licence and also held no valid insurance for the car.Watson appeared in the dock at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Wednesday, where she pleaded guilty to four charges.Fiscal depute Miss Stuart told the court that Watson had previously pleaded guilty by letter and was driving a white Vauxhall Corsa when she pulled into the takeaway car park at about .am.The fiscal said that an employee spotted Watson was ldquohaving trouble driving the car and suspected her of being under the influence of a substance when she was ldquostruggling to speak when ordering the food.Solicitor Paul Smith said his client was expecting her first child in April and the offence had been ldquoa very poor error of judgement.Mr Smith added that Watson had taken Valium at a friendrsquos home earlier that evening and now ldquoaccepts she was unfit to drive the vehicle.The brief said that Watson was a care worker and was currently a single woman and living alone.Sherf Roderick Flinn told the woman that she had committed ldquoa serious offence and banned her from driving for  months. The sherf also issued Watson with a pound fine.Watson pleaded guilty to driving a vehicle with only a provisional licence at McDonaldrsquos car park, Kinnaird Park, Edinburgh, on July  last year.She also admitted a further three charges of having no valid insurance, being unfit to drive through drink or drugs, and failing to give police details of the driver of the vehicle during the same incident.

title: tims-tales-stars-sky
story: I HAVE a term: the lsquoupside down skyrsquo. I use this phrase to describe the spectacle of street lights at night when viewed from a vantage point.One of the best places in East Lothian to view the lsquoupside down skyrsquo is from the road by Farsquoside Castle. This vantage point gives you views over Wallyford, Musselburgh, Portobello and Edinburgh beyond.These urban areas create a sea of lights which look like a sky full of bright stars, except, of course, itrsquos lsquoupside downrsquo and theyrsquore not really stars. But it looks spectacular in its own way. In fact, views with bright city lights are these days often considered tourist attractions.But Irsquove recently realised something: while the lsquostarsrsquo of the lsquoupside down skyrsquo are getting more numerous and extensive every year, the real stars in the actual sky are becoming more dficult to see at least where I live.Literally thousands upon thousands of houses are being built in the western part of our county. Much of the rural landscape in this part of East Lothian, which I knew when I was a child, is going fast.Most of me understands and accepts the needs for this, but a part feels sad at the loss of a recognisable landscape. And already I have noticed that a by-product of this has been increased light pollution in areas close to where I live. It is going to get much more noticeable as more development takes place.I know many people will say there are many more things to think about, especially in late January, when the Christmas turkey is coming home to roost and all those bills have to be paid at a time when we are already financially drained from festive expenditure, and stressed out. Thank goodness for Burns suppers, a highlight of a month that often seems both the darkest and longest of the year.But this is all the more reason to pause. When was the last time you really had the opportunity to sit under a dark night sky full of visible stars  This is one of naturersquos free gts and stargazing has real benefits for our mental health and emotional wellbeing.I remember some years ago, when visiting a friend in a very rural part of Scotland, I went out to put something in the bin. My friend came out to seeI was OK, as I hadnrsquot ed after  minutes. I had been struck by the beauty and power of the starlit sky, unpolluted by city lights. Without noticing the time, I had sat just gazing at the universe above me.I can remember the sense of awe and peace it created. Sure, part of it was also the quiet and stillness in that area, but sitting under the canopy of stars is what overwhelmed me in that moment.Itrsquos an experience fewer of us can enjoy because of the increase in light pollution, but also noise and general busyness all around us. So we often donrsquot even realise what wersquore missing. Perhaps there is a cause and effect here: the less you notice the absence of something, the less you think itrsquos important or relevant.Our ancient ancestors understood its power. But I think we have lost the sense. I recently asked a group of young people how many of them had sat under the stars and just gazed and wondered at them. Sadly, none had done so, and some thought the idea ldquoweird. I think a lot of adults would share that opinion.But taking time to sit and really wonder at an unpolluted night sky can fill us with awe, as I experienced that evening at my friendrsquos house. It makes us feel small and in so doing it puts our worries and anxieties in perspective. It can promote inner peace and calm.For sure, the bills wonrsquot go away neither will the stress at work or whatever is dominating your thoughts most of the day. But in taking time to pause and wonder at the vast and almost timeless beauty of the stars, your soul gets time to catch up. It can help you see things dferently, in a more creative way. Itrsquos a form of meditation with something bigger than we can imagine, but also something incredibly beautul.And itrsquos fascinating, as you try to identy the dferent constellations, and perhaps realise how much you donrsquot know or have forgotten. Could you identy the northern star, and what constellations can you see  Sailors in days of old were experts at identying the stars to aid direction, but Irsquom sure they also marvelled at the unhindered beauty and mystery of them as well.There are still many places in our county where we can be wrapped in star-lit darkness. But as the lsquoupside down skyrsquo gets bigger and brighter, the real stars are fading in so many places.The real shame is, as the stars disappear from our sight, they may disappear from our consciousness as well.Letrsquos not let that happen. Let us gt our children, and ourselves, with the noticing and gazing at the real stars in our sky and somehow find the time, even briefly, to stargaze.

title: garry-oconnor-referees-haddington-amateur-teams-successful-charity-match
story: Haddington Town FC took time out over the festive period for a special friendly in aid of Back Onside.Former Hibernian and Scotland striker Garry OrsquoConnor, who is an ambassador of the good cause, refereed the match, which saw members of the amateur teamrsquos squad come up against one another on January .Matt OrsquoConnell, chairman of the club, which was formed last year, said they were determined to help support the charity, which helps young people and adults who face mental health challenges.He said: ldquoWersquore a club that was founded on the idea of bringing local guys together into a positive social and active environment.ldquoItrsquos well documented that the highest proportion of suicide across Scotland is men aged - and thatrsquos something we hope to positively redress in our town by facilitating a great environment in which local guys can improve not only their physical but also their mental health.ldquoOur connection with the charity Back Onside was really born of their slogan, #SupportThroughSport, a powerful statement that really resonated with us.ldquoTheyrsquore a great charity who are doing a hell of a lot across the UK and so for us, a small amateur club barely nine months old, to play a small part in helping a charity who share our ethos was immensely rewarding.Haddington Town play on Sunday mornings in Division Two of the Lothian and Edinburgh Amateur Football Association , alongside fellow county side Meadowmill.The charity match, played at Knox Academy, finished - in favour of the lsquoawayrsquo Haddington Town team.Libby Emmerson, founder and CEO of Back Onside, said: ldquoWe are beyond grateful for the support received from Haddington Town Amateur Football Club and guest referee Garry OrsquoConnor.ldquoAs a small charity with a huge clientele, community events such as the Haddington Town AFC charity match are key to raising funds and awareness so that we can continue to support those facing mental health challenges.Mr OrsquoConnell thanked everyone for their support, with the match raising pound, ndash more than double the target.He said: ldquoHuge thanks to Libby Emmerson, FES FM and Garry OrsquoConnor. We would also like to thank the local businesses who helped us: The Green, The Grain, Tyneside Tavern and Print Factory Scotland.

title: brewery-shuts-ahead-archerfield-walled-garden-redevelopment-plan
story: Knops moved into Archerfield and opened the brewery in , occupying a third of the available space.However, with refurbishment plans in the works and the breweryrsquos lease on the space up for renewal at the end of last year, rather than grant renewal, a decision was made to close the brewery, a decision described as the ldquomost sensible thing to do.Robert Knops, owner of Knops Brewery, decided to close the brewery for good rather than carry on in a dferent venue.Some of Knopsrsquo most popular beers included Black Cork, Calornia Common and East Coast Pale Ale.Plans to overhaul Archerfield Walled Garden have been in the works for the past couple of years.Ross McGregor, director of operations for Archerfield Estates Limited, said: ldquoThose at the brewery have done a really fantastic job over the years.ldquoTheyrsquove known about the closure for the past two years because thatrsquos how long we have been planning this [refurbishment] for.ldquoSome of the plans on the table include re-doing the entire inside of the building and turning it into a garden shop along with updating our cafe and food market.ldquoThe project is a major refurbishment and we hope to improve a lot of areas to make better use of the space we have, for example to help in dealing with events.He added: ldquoThis is a really positive thing for the area. The business has been growing over the last few years and now we are adding to that. We aim to make it slicker for the customer as well as a simpler and more beautul place.Plans for the upgrade, which are still to be finalised, could see the walled garden take on an even greater garden and floral theme.Other plans include an expansion to the cafe, with hopes the food used there could be grown on site.The childrenrsquos area could also see a revamp with a covered outdoor area containing an extra - seats.Planning permission for the renovation has been approved and work is set to begin either later on this year or early next year.Mr McGregor said: ldquoWe are now working with the building contractors to decide on when this will be completed.ldquoIrsquom hoping it will be this year but it all depends on the building warrant and what timescale the builders come back with.The business will need to close for about two months when the work is going on but it is not yet known when this will happen.

title: shock-bouquet-popular-hairdressers-grave-vanishes
story: Melvin died on September  after succumbing to heart failure while on holiday in Tenere aged .His daughter, -year-old Hannah, who works as an accident and emergency nurse in Glasgow, bought the winter-themed bouquet and placed it on his grave in the cemetery at Athelstaneford on Christmas Eve.His we Lorna, who lives near Gilmerton House and visits Melvinrsquos grave regularly, told the Courier: ldquoMy daughter visited the cemetery to place the bouquet and Irsquod placed a wreath which I bought for him beforehand.ldquoMelvin loved Christmas and decorations so we put something there to give him some nice Christmas surroundings.ldquoI went back on December  and it was still there but when I went back on January  it was gone, the vase and wreath were still there but the flowers werenrsquot.ldquoI looked everywhere and even asked a member of staff but couldnrsquot find it. I think someone has stolen it.She added: ldquoIrsquom really shocked because I just canrsquot understand why someone would do something like this.ldquoThe whole thing is very untoward, absolutely disgusting, and has made me quite upset. Itrsquos quite obvious itrsquos at a grave so I donrsquot know why someone would take it.ldquoI thought it might have been an animal or that someone had moved it to a dferent grave, so I looked around each grave but they all still had their flower decorations.Lorna added: ldquoHannah is just really hurt and upset.ldquoShe is only , shersquos just lost her dad and wants to put something on his grave to honour him.The pair hope the person responsible ldquofeels ashamed and s the bouquet.

title: scott-glynn-remembered-walk-scott-may
story: The walk was set up by Tranent after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Scott passed away on New Yearrsquos Day.Since its inception in , the event has raised more than pound, for local charities and good causes.Last Friday, on social media, the Walk With Scott Foundation announced: ldquoWalk with Scott  is on!ldquoStick Saturday, May , , in your diaries, get those walking shoes out, and look out for further information in the coming weeks.Last year, more than  people turned out to complete a .-mile walk around East Lothian in aid of the foundation.The group set out from Cockenzie, heading to Musselburgh they followed the River Esk to Whitecraig, then went along the old Pencaitland railway, on to Boggs Holdings, up through Butterdean Woods, then along to Longniddry before turning back along the coast road to Cockenzie.For more information, search lsquoWalk With Scott Foundationrsquo on Facebook.

title: wetherspoon-pubs-tell-parents-children-can-two-drinks
story: Its a question thats sparked a debate on social media after it was revealed Wetherspoon pubs limit parents to two alcoholic drinks eachthey have children with them.The rule came to light after a picture was taken of a poster in a pub in Kent.The poster, which has since been taken down, read: "As part of our licensing it is our responsibility to ensure that we are protecting children from harm."Therefore adults in charge of children will be allowed to have one alcoholic drink and a further alcoholic drink with a sit-down meal."It has been a crime since  to be drunk in charge of a child under the age of seven in a public place.The offence can be punished by a fine or up to a month in jail.A spokesman for Wetherspoon,which has a pub on Musselburghs Bridge Street, The David Macbeth Moir,said: "The manager took the decision to put the poster in the pub to emphasise to customers that she would not allow parents to drink while their children were running round uncontrolled in the pub."The notice had a positive effect, with mostly good feedback."Wetherspoonadded: "There is a guideline, though not a policy, that we will serve the adult a maximum of two alcoholic drinks with their meal."The reason is that we dont want children being unruly in the pubs and parents thinking they can continue to drink while this happens."

title: lion-king-magical-stage-production-spine-tingling-sensation
story: The loveable and heartwarming story of Simbas rollercoaster journey to become King of the Pride Lands is a firm family cartoon favourite but can it really be transformed into a theatrical extravaganza It certainly can!From the moment the lights dimmed in the Edinburgh Playhouse you are transported into a magical kingdom immersed with the most amazing colour and sounds as the anthemic Circle of Le  song filled the room.Other stand out songs included the fun, lighthearted, I Just Cant Wait to be King performed by young Simba and Nala and the poignant, He lives in You, thanks to the genius of Elton John and Tim Rice.Each character was performed like a masterpiece by an impressive and erse cast but special mention has to go to Thandazile Soni whose portrayal of Rafiki had the audience spellbound with her humour, top vocals and creative take on the famous mandrill.Richard Hurst as Scar brought the classic baddie to le and Jean-Luc Guizonne was majestic in his rendition of Mufasa.While it was a laugh a minute from the brilliant Matthew Forbes as Zazu who couldnt help but make a gag about the rivalry between the Capital and Glasgow.From the infectious laughs of the dimwitted hyenas to the heartwarming friendship of duo Timon and Pumbaa, you connected with every character - a credit to the charm of the story.The attention to detail was phenomenal from the unique movement of characters shadowing animals to a tee to the human props that brought the set to le.The scenery, costumes, puppetry in their entirety were breathtaking, taking you into African savannah paradise.The Lion King is full of good fun, show stomping tunes and a treat for your eyes and ears which showcases the best of the West End right on our doorstep in Edinburgh.With  years competing as one of the all-time most successful productions, youll be left wondering why you didnt go and see this sooner.This show is the King of the stage.

title: car-plummets-20ft-off-dunbar-sea-wall-onto-beach
story: Thankfully,no-one was in the Vauxhall Zafira when it suffered suspected handbrake failure and plummeted onto Dunbars East Beach from the towns Lamer Street at about .am.There were walkers on the beach but they were not nearby.The Courier understands the cars owners were on a day trip to Dunbar from Edinburgh.One passer-by said: "Luckily, no-one was in the car at the time - it was not the day out that the car owners had planned!"A tow truck appeared later in the day to take the battered car - which had flipped onto its roof - off the beach.
